author: By Jenny Block
title: A Promise to ‘Always Say Yes to the Animals’
description: Jill Brown and Sidney A. Beard, who live with their two daughters and a menagerie of adopted pets, connected through the dating app Tinder on Labor Day weekend in 2015.
content: Sidney A. Beard and Jill Brown have six cats, three hens, two dogs, two rabbits and a Belgian draft horse, all rescues. “The only one who doesn’t live in the house is the horse because we couldn’t sneak him into the neighborhood,” Ms. Brown said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steven Lee Myers and Amy Chang Chien
title: Chinese Journalist Detained After Criticizing Government-Sponsored Blockbuster
description: The police arrested Luo Changping on Thursday, two days after he questioned China’s role in the Korean War, the subject of China’s box office hit “The Battle at Lake Changjin.”
content: Luo Changping built a reputation as a muckraking journalist in China, a place where few dare pursue the calling, until he was forced out of the industry in 2014. Now a businessman, he has run afoul of the authorities again, this time over a critique spurred by a blockbuster movie about the Korean War.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Conrad de Aenlle
title: Economic and Earnings Concerns Begin to Weigh on Stocks
description: After having few cares about the markets all year, investors are getting nervous as the Fed signals that harsher policies are on the way.
content: Wall Street’s imperviousness to bad news, which enabled stocks to double in value from their pandemic panic lows, may be starting to crack.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steven Erlanger
title: Why Is Poland Fighting the Supremacy of European Union Courts?
description: Poland argues that its courts should supersede the bloc’s top court. The E.U. sharply disagrees.
content: BRUSSELS — Poland threw down the gauntlet to the European Union on Thursday when its Constitutional Tribunal issued a judgment that the Polish Constitution in some cases supersedes rulings by the bloc’s highest court.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ivy Manners
title: What We Saw at the New York Bridal Fashion Week
description: The latest wedding dress trends from the virtual and in-person bridal runway.
content: With more weddings now taking place since the start of the pandemic, designers were especially excited to debut their latest bridal collections at New York Bridal Fashion Week, held Oct. 6 to 8. The event included some in-person presentations, though most of their 2022 fall and spring ensembles were viewed virtually.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vincent M. Mallozzi
title: Seven Years Later, They Picked Up Where They Left Off
description: Raisa Marie Lopez-Rhoden and Ndubuisi Ugoeze Richard Okereke began dating in 2009, but soon after they were forging their own career paths in different cities.
content: Raisa Marie Lopez-Rhoden and Ndubuisi Ugoeze Richard Okereke met at a Halloween party in 2008, when she was dressed as a schoolgirl and he a pirate. They became friends.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Allen
title: Louise Farrenc, 19th-Century Composer, Surges Back Into Sound
description: Orchestras are turning to her turbulent symphonies; pianists, to her sophisticated études; chamber musicians, to her superb Nonet.
content: Read the reviews that the composer, pianist and teacher Louise Farrenc received in the middle of the 19th century, and the kinds of gendered, backhanded compliments that male critics have so often given to female artists pop up with tiresome regularity.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Cora Engelbrecht and Marc Santora
title: Potential Peace Prize winners are as varied as the issues facing humanity.
description: In a year marked by climate change-driven disasters, political turmoil and the enduring devastation wrought by the coronavirus, the Norwegian Nobel Committee is choosing from a diverse array of 329 candidates for the Nobel Peace Prize.
content: In a year marked by climate change-driven disasters, political turmoil and the enduring devastation wrought by the coronavirus, the Norwegian Nobel Committee is choosing from a diverse array of 329 candidates for the Nobel Peace Prize.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ed Shanahan
title: U.S. Charges Ex-Taliban Commander in Killing of 3 Soldiers in ’08 Attack
description: The man, Haji Najibullah, was charged last year with kidnapping an American journalist and two Afghan nationals months after the deadly assault.
content: On a June day in 2008, three U.S. soldiers and an Afghan interpreter were ambushed and killed when their Humvee convoy was hit during a combat patrol by mines and rocket-propelled grenades about 50 miles south of Kabul. At least one of the men was dragged off and dismembered, Afghan and Western officials said at the time.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maya Phillips
title: ‘Lackawanna Blues’ Review: A Soulful Master Class in Storytelling
description: Ruben Santiago-Hudson brings his tender and vibrant autobiographical show to Broadway, honoring the woman who not only raised him but also kept a cast of misfits in line.
content: It takes a village, the saying goes. But if you’re one member of a motley crew of characters in 1950s Lackawanna, N.Y., well, then, you might say it takes a boardinghouse, and a generous woman, to keep everyone in line.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: Your Friday Briefing
description: A Senate agreement on the debt ceiling.
content: The Senate passed legislation last night to temporarily raise the debt ceiling through early December, after 11 Republicans joined every Democrat in voting to take up the bill, clearing the 60-vote threshold needed to break the G.O.P. filibuster and staving off the threat of a first-ever federal default. The final vote was 50 to 48, with senators split down party lines.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicole Daniels
title: Lesson of the Day: ‘The Facebook Whistle-Blower Testifies’
description: A former employee’s congressional testimony shed light on some of the social media giant’s most problematic practices. In this lesson, students will discuss how, or if, the company should be held accountable.
content: Featured Podcast: “The Daily” episode “The Facebook Whistle-Blower Testifies” hosted by Astead W. Herndon with special guest Sheera Frenkel
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Trish Bendix
title: Late Night Dives Into a New Senate Report on Trump
description: “So far, I’ve only read the title page, and it seems to be about how the former president and his allies pressured D.O.J. to overturn the 2020 election,” Stephen Colbert said on Thursday.
content: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Casselman
title: Jobs Report Offers Little Reassurance on U.S. Economy
description: The gain of 194,000 in September showed the continuing grip of the latest coronavirus wave, though unemployment fell to 4.8 percent.
content: Job growth slowed to the year’s weakest pace last month as the latest coronavirus wave dashed hopes of an imminent return to normal for the U.S. economy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ann Carrns
title: In a ‘War for Talent,’ Employers Hold the Line on Health Benefit Costs
description: Companies may be picking up more of the expense while also emphasizing cheaper remote care. Some are offering perks like “lifestyle” stipends.
content: Home delivery of food and snacks, to replace workplace cafeterias. Health club memberships and “lifestyle” stipends. Doulas for pregnant workers and breast milk services for new mothers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brooke Harrington
title: When Reputation Matters, Leaks Like the Pandora Papers Can Be Very Effective
description: Technology and public opinion are shifting the balance against elites’ use of offshore financial services.
content: Some reports on the Pandora Papers have featured colorful and scintillating headlines (“Secret money, swanky real estate and a Monte Carlo mystery”), but there is a drab, depressing familiarity to the nearly 12 million leaked confidential financial records that throw light on the opaque wealth of powerful public figures around the world.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Dooley and Hisako Ueno
title: A Tiny Gas Meter? The More Mundane the Better for Japan’s Capsule Toys.
description: Isolated in their plastic spheres, pint-size reproductions of everyday items feel like a metaphor for Covid-era life.
content: TOKYO — Yoshiaki Yamanishi set out to create the most boring toy imaginable.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Johnny Diaz
title: Florida’s Board of Education approves cutbacks to 8 school districts over mask mandates.
description: Thursday’s decision means that the districts could face cutbacks that are equal to their school board members’ salaries for requiring students and staff to wear masks.
content: The political battle in Florida over masks in schools escalated this week, as the state Board of Education voted to authorize sanctions on eight local school districts for not following instructions from Gov. Ron DeSantis’s administration that make masks optional.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By J. Alex Tarquinio
title: Surging Inflation and Volatile Bond Prices Are Challenging Investors
description: There are remedies for the problems in the bond market, experts say, but none of them are perfect.
content: Investors seeking to steer clear of the twin hazards of rising inflation and falling bond prices might feel as if they’re being asked to navigate between the mythological sea creatures Scylla and Charybdis.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Niraj Chokshi, Clifford Krauss and Ivan Penn
title: Are Tesla and Texas a Perfect Match? It’s Questionable.
description: While its C.E.O., Elon Musk, and the state’s conservative lawmakers share libertarian sensibilities, they differ greatly on climate change and renewable energy.
content: Tesla’s move from Silicon Valley to Texas makes sense in many ways: The company’s chief executive, Elon Musk, and the conservative lawmakers who run the state share a libertarian philosophy, favoring few regulations and low taxes. Texas also has room for a company with grand ambitions to grow.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eugenia C. South
title: To Combat Gun Violence, Clean Up the Neighborhood
description: Gun violence interventions often focus on high-risk people. To achieve meaningful change, policy makers should focus on high-risk places, too.
content: PHILADELPHIA — Until a Black man turns 45, his most likely cause of death is homicide. After each such violent death, traumatic shock waves pierce through family and friends. Whole neighborhoods suffer. In some communities with high rates of violent crime, babies are more likely to be born early, children are more likely to struggle in school and adults are more likely to report being depressed, as well as face increased risk of heart disease.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ceylan Yeginsu
title: As International Travel Returns, Confusion Over Vaccines Reigns
description: Fragmented rules about which vaccines will be accepted and what documentation is needed, as well as a lack of compatibility between vaccine apps, have left many travelers frustrated.
content: When Turkey was taken off Britain’s red list for travel last month, Sally Morrow, an English expatriate living in the Turkish capital of Ankara, rushed to her computer and booked flights to London, so that she could reunite with her ailing parents after more than six months apart.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma Grillo
title: Salvaging a Poor First Impression
description: At a dinner with friends, Elaine Kwon was put off by how uninterested Jordan Taylor first seemed in getting to know her. By the end of the night, she was rethinking her initial opinion.
content: On the night he met Elaine Sunmi Kwon in Los Angeles in September 2012, Jordan Hayes Taylor was exhausted. He had spent the evening before celebrating his birthday, and when it came time to have dinner with some of his friends from high school, “I was hanging on by a thread,” Mr. Taylor, 37, said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anemona Hartocollis
title: 2 Parents Are Convicted in the Varsity Blues Admissions Trial
description: John Wilson, a private equity financier, and Gamal Abdelaziz, a former casino executive, were the first people to stand trial in the federal investigation.
content: Two parents were found guilty in federal court in Boston on Friday for participating in a bribery scheme to have their children fraudulently admitted as athletic recruits to some of the most prestigious universities in the country.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Norimitsu Onishi and Aurelien Breeden
title: Sexual Abuse Revelations Accelerate Sense of a French Church in Retreat
description: The abuse of more than 200,000 minors by clergy over the past seven decades has shaken the nation and what was once a pillar of French society.
content: PARIS — The Catholic Church in France was once so powerful that it was considered a state within a state. In Roman Catholicism’s global hierarchy, France cemented its position as far back as the fifth century, when it became known as the “eldest daughter of the church.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rory Smith
title: Saudi Arabia, Newcastle and Soccer’s Worship of Money
description: The sale of a Premier League team symbolizes a sport’s unashamed devotion to wealth above all else.
content: One single sentence, printed in block capitals, emblazoned on a laminated banner, captured it all: all of the pain and resentment and angst and fury of all those years spent under the turgid, wearying, bleak years of Mike Ashley’s ownership of Newcastle United, that decade and a half when the club’s owner seemed to take pleasure, after a while, in draining his own fans of spirit, and pleasure, and hope.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daniel Politi
title: Court in Argentina Dismisses Charges Against Kirchner in Bombing Case
description: Cristina Fernández de Kirchner, now the vice president, had been accused of conspiring with Iran to thwart an investigation into a 1994 attack on a Jewish center in Buenos Aires.
content: BUENOS AIRES — A court in Argentina has dismissed a criminal case against Vice President Cristina Fernández de Kirchner that accused her of conspiring with Iran to cover up that country’s suspected involvement in a 1994 bombing of a Jewish community center in Buenos Aires.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Butterflies
description: Tell us a story, real or made up, that is inspired by this image.
content: Use your imagination to write the opening of a short story or poem inspired by this illustration — or, tell us about a memory from your own life that this image makes you think of.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicolas Rapold
title: Bonding With Léa Seydoux
description: The French actress has roles in “No Time to Die,” “The French Dispatch” and the upcoming “France.” She sees acting as a way to connect to the world.
content: The stories in Wes Anderson’s “The French Dispatch” take place in the fictional town of Ennui-sur-Blasé. Léa Seydoux — who plays a prison guard who models for an inmate — finds the name hilarious.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vincent M. Mallozzi
title: Sticking Together in Sickness and in Health
description: Molly Kathleen Atwater and Thomas Matthew Pulisic were happily dating for several months when she received a life-threatening diagnosis.
content: While exchanging vows on Sept. 11, Molly Kathleen Atwater and Thomas Matthew Pulisic purposely skipped the words “for better or worse, in sickness and health.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Kirsch
title: What to Do This Weekend
description: ‘Squid Game’ and loaf cake.
content: Welcome. Last week, a reader recommended the Netflix series “Squid Game,” describing it as “a tapestry made with threads from ‘The Hunger Games,’ ‘The Purge,’ ‘Rounders’ and the creepy elements of Willy Wonka.” Ted Sarandos, co-C.E.O. of Netflix, recently said there’s “a very good chance it’s going to be our biggest show ever.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas Gibbons-Neff and Wali Arian
title: ISIS Bomber Kills Dozens at Shiite Mosque in Northern Afghanistan
description: The Islamic State Khorasan claimed responsibility for the attack in Kunduz, continuing its campaign of predation against the Hazara Shiite minority into a new era of Taliban rule.
content: KABUL, Afghanistan — An Islamic State suicide bomber devastated a Shiite mosque in the northern Afghan city of Kunduz on Friday, killing dozens of worshipers in a deadly continuation of the terrorist group’s campaign against the Hazara minority.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charanna Alexander
title: Love Letter: Finding Comfort in Silence
description: And: Love and sobriety.
content: Alice Hoffman, the writer of this week’s Modern Love essay, always found comfort in the long walks and lengthy conversations she shared with her friend of 60 years. However, when her friend’s husband died, both were at a loss for words for the first time in their friendship.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Irwin
title: The New Jobs Numbers Are Pretty Good, Actually
description: They fell far short of analyst expectations, but they reflect a steady expansion that is more rapid than other recent recoveries.
content: It’s not as bad as it looks.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aina J. Khan
title: England reduces its ‘red list’ for travel restrictions to just seven countries.
description: The British government said the narrowing of the restrictions, which require hotel quarantine for arrivals, partly reflected “increased vaccination efforts around the globe.”
content: England has reduced to just seven the number of “red list” countries that it considers the highest coronavirus risk and from which it requires travelers to quarantine in government-designated hotels upon arrival.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alice Hoffman
title: The One Thing We Couldn’t Talk About
description: When the bad news finally arrived, neither one of us — dear friends for 60 years — knew what to say.
content: It was late at night when the phone rang. I lived alone with my dog and didn’t expect anyone to be calling. I rightly assumed that only bad news arrived at this hour. I had recently experienced a series of plagues. Flies. Rats. Bats. Divorce. And now Covid.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Juliet Macur and Kevin Draper
title: ‘Devastated, Disgusted, but I’m Not Shocked’
description: The players in the National Women’s Soccer League, tired of abuse and harassment, are speaking up and seizing power. But the way forward for the troubled league isn’t clear.
content: In the top professional soccer league for women in North America, everyone understood that the power primarily rested with men: the team owners, executives and coaches who controlled the athletes and their careers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Bahr
title: Biden’s Pick to Lead N.E.A. Sees Culture as a Community Building Tool
description: Maria Rosario Jackson, a veteran arts administrator with a background in urban planning, is recognized as an expert in using culture to spur economic development.
content: President Joseph R. Biden Jr.’s new nominee to lead the National Endowment for the Arts is a veteran arts administrator and tenured professor at Arizona State University with a background in urban planning and a history of embracing the importance of the arts at the neighborhood level.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joanne Kaufman
title: Pandemic Decluttering
description: With little else to do during lockdown, many people decided to do some good housekeeping, and thrift shops are booming.
content: Lizbeth Meredith never considered herself a hoarder. Perish the thought this minute.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lara Jakes and Maria Abi-Habib
title: At Mexico-U.S. Security Talks, Migration Question Is Largely Avoided
description: As diplomats from both countries began negotiating a new security agreement on Friday, the focus was on stopping criminal activity while the border crisis was conspicuously sidestepped.
content: MEXICO CITY — The United States and Mexico began overhauling an aged security agreement on Friday to better confront the flow of criminal activity between the two nations, but officials at the high-level talks conspicuously sought to avoid focusing on the ever-growing migrant crisis on their shared border.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roxane Gay
title: You Are Not Where You Work
description: Especially if you have good reason to stay employed by — and be concerned about — a global online retailer.
content: Send questions about the office, money, careers and work-life balance to workfriend@nytimes.com. Include your name and location, or a request to remain anonymous. Letters may be edited.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Traub
title: Listening, and Listening Again, to Latino Voters
description: Jennifer Medina interviews her subjects multiple times — sometimes spending as many as 50 hours with them — to understand their complex political attitudes.
content: From the 2016 to the 2020 elections, Donald Trump improved his performance among certain segments of Latino voters, prompting surprised reactions from many journalists and people who work in politics. But this phenomenon was clear to those carefully tracking Latino sentiment — and few were doing that more diligently than the Times political reporter Jennifer Medina, whose parents are Panamanian.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alix Wall
title: Parallel Lives Converge, With Help From an App
description: Careers in finance led Daniil Kalyuzhny and Nina Naydenova to meet. Shared experience immigrating from Eastern Europe as children led them to marry.
content: Daniil Kalyuzhny and Nina Naydenova disagree about the nature of their first meeting. In 2016, Mr. Kalyuzhny, then an M.B.A. student at Cornell University, attended a recruiting event for business school students at J.P. Morgan Chase & Company, where Ms. Naydenova is an executive director of mergers and acquisitions. She describes the encounter as an interview, while he considers it more of an interrogation. What they do agree on is that not even the faintest spark flew.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Jason Karaian, Sarah Kessler, Stephen Gandel, Michael J. de la Merced, Lauren Hirsch and Ephrat Livni
title: BlackRock’s Transfer of Power
description: Larry Fink is giving some investors more say over voting their shares.
content: Larry Fink, the C.E.O. of BlackRock, which has nearly $10 trillion in assets, is widely considered to be the world’s most powerful investor. His annual letters to leaders of the nation’s largest companies are must-reads that change corporate behavior.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shaila Dewan
title: A Jailed Indian Boy Chases His Scrap of Sky
description: For the 9-year-old narrator of Padma Venkatraman’s “Born Behind Bars,” life was but a dream.
content: BORN BEHIND BARSBy Padma Venkatraman
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Morgan Campbell
title: What to Watch in the Tyson Fury vs. Deontay Wilder Heavyweight Fight
description: Fury and Wilder are fighting for the third time, headlining a pay-per-view card that begins at 9 p.m. Eastern on Saturday.
content: Tyson Fury won the most recent boxing contest, stopping Deontay Wilder in seven rounds to claim the World Boxing Council heavyweight title in February 2020. But Wilder won the latest fight, prevailing in court to enforce the rematch clause in his contract and set up their trilogy fight, which will take place Saturday night in Las Vegas.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Press
title: The Film Industry Wants to Keep the Status Quo? Then Shut It Down.
description: Hollywood is back in full swing, grinding those behind the scenes down to the bone. Can a new union contract fix that?
content: In 2015, Cutter Ray Palacios, an actor from Texas, moved to Los Angeles. While auditioning for roles, he found himself working primarily as a production assistant (P.A.), a job that can entail transporting actors to and from set, moving equipment, sorting mail, and running errands for producers or other members of the crew.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Tanzanian Writer Cited for Exploring Themes on Fate of the Refugee
description: Quotation of the Day for Friday, October 8, 2021.
content: “The thing that motivated the whole experience of writing for me was this idea of losing your place in the world.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Word of the Day: allay
description: This word has appeared in 63 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tim Gray
title: Farmland Is Valuable, but Buying It Is Tricky for Fund Investors
description: Arable land is scarce and demand for food is rising. Mutual funds can capture some of that value indirectly.
content: Bill Gates has bought enormous tracts of farmland. Warren E. Buffett acquired a 400-acre Nebraska farm in the ’80s that produced corn and soybeans, reasoning that this investment in agriculture “had no downside and potentially had substantial upside.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rick Gladstone
title: Anti-Nobel sentiment has spawned alternative awards over the years.
description: Some authoritarian countries have  created their own anti-Nobel awards.
content: The choice of a Nobel Peace Prize recipient has often been viewed by autocratic governments as a provocative and hostile act, especially when the winner is a political opponent, an advocate of free expression or an agitator for greater liberties. Some authoritarian countries have even created their own anti-Nobel awards.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Isaac
title: Facebook and its apps suffer another outage.
description: All of Facebook’s main products — Instagram, WhatsApp, Messenger and the “big blue app” of Facebook — were inaccessible to at least some users around 3 p.m. Eastern time.
content: SAN FRANCISCO — Facebook and its family of apps were inaccessible for about two hours on Friday afternoon, the second time in a week that the social network experienced widespread problems with its services.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Astead W. Herndon, Jessica Cheung, Lynsea Garrison, Sydney Harper, Eric Krupke, Soraya Shockley, M.J. Davis Lin, Patricia Willens, Dan Powell, Elisheba Ittoop, Marion Lozano and Chris Wood
title: A Troubling C.I.A. Admission
description: In a top secret cable, the agency said it had lost dozens of informants. How did this happen?
content: Last week, American counterintelligence officials sent a short but explosive message to every C.I.A. station and base around the world: There has been an informant problem.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shashank Bengali and Marc Santora
title: Journalists Maria Ressa and Dmitri Muratov are awarded the Nobel Peace Prize.
description: The two, who lead independent news outlets in the Philippines and Russia, despite government repression, were recognized for “their courageous fight for freedom of expression.”
content: Seeking to bolster press freedoms as journalists find themselves under increasing pressure from authoritarian governments and other hostile forces, the Norwegian Nobel Committee on Friday awarded the Peace Prize to two journalists thousands of miles apart for their tireless efforts to hold the powerful to account.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kellen Browning
title: Apple Appeals App Store Ruling in Fight With Epic Games
description: At the heart of the legal battle is the power Apple wields over its lucrative App Store.
content: Apple asked a federal appeals court on Friday to throw out a legal decision that would require the tech giant to tweak its strict App Store rules and force it to allow app developers to inform customers of ways to pay for subscriptions and services outside the App Store.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shashank Bengali
title: Maria Ressa is only the 18th woman to win the Nobel Peace Prize.
description: Past recipients include the women’s rights activist Jane Addams; the Catholic saint Mother Teresa; and the African leader Ellen Johnson Sirleaf.
content: In receiving the Nobel Peace Prize on Friday, the Philippine journalist Maria Ressa became only the 18th woman to be selected for the award in its 120-year history.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Weinstein
title: Food Your Kids Might Actually Eat
description: Four-cheese flatbreads, crunchy chicken cutlets, breakfast burritos: These recipes may even appeal to the pickiest eaters.
content: The other day, my younger daughter, who is not quite 2, was given a piece of homemade blueberry pie. She screamed in agony. How dare someone offer her pie!
source.name: The New York Times

title: Eating What You Fear and a ‘Pacemaker for the Brain’: The Week in Narrated Articles
description: Five articles from around The Times, narrated just for you.
content: This weekend, listen to a collection of narrated articles from around The New York Times, read aloud by the reporters who wrote them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lynsey Chutel
title: Mozambique closes its popular beaches despite low Covid infections.
description: With only 5 percent of the country’s adults vaccinated, Mozambique took the precaution amid fears of a renewed spread of the coronavirus.
content: While wealthier countries with higher coronavirus vaccination rates are increasingly reopening their borders and their economies, nations with more restricted vaccine access are having to make tougher moves.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jon Pareles, Jon Caramanica, Isabelia Herrera and Giovanni Russonello
title: Mitski’s Sharp Take on a Creative Life, and 12 More New Songs
description: Hear tracks by Arca featuring Sia, Kelis, Tambino and others.
content: Every Friday, pop critics for The New York Times weigh in on the week’s most notable new songs and videos. Just want the music? Listen to the Playlist on Spotify here (or find our profile: nytimes). Like what you hear? Let us know at theplaylist@nytimes.com and sign up for our Louder newsletter, a once-a-week blast of our pop music coverage.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Trip Gabriel
title: ‘Long Overdue’: Liberal Voters Hold Firm to Biden’s Stronger Safety Net
description: In the deep-blue Seattle district represented by Pramila Jayapal, a leading progressive in Congress, voters see the Democrats’ left wing as ascendant and want it to play hardball against moderates.
content: SEATTLE — In the bluest congressional district in the Pacific Northwest, Democrats range from liberal to even more liberal.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By ‘The Ezra Klein Show'
title: Let’s Talk About the Anxiety Freedom Can Cause
description: The poet and theorist Maggie Nelson examines freedom and its limitations.
content: Maggie Nelson is a poet, critic and cultural theorist whose work includes the award-winning 2016 book “The Argonauts.” Her newest work, “On Freedom,” pierces right into the heart of America’s founding idea: What if there’s no such thing as freedom, at least not freedom as a state of enduring liberation?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adeel Hassan
title: The L.A. sheriff rejects the county’s vaccine mandate for his officers, saying too many would quit.
description: The comments from Sheriff Alex Villanueva, a politically divisive figure, underscores the difficulty of trying to lift lagging vaccination rates among law enforcement officers across the country.
content: The sheriff of Los Angeles County reiterated this week that he would not compel members of his staff to be inoculated against the coronavirus, in defiance of the county’s order that all of its 110,000 employees show proof of vaccination by Oct. 1.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ed Park
title: How Comics Responded to Our Locked-Down, Anxious Covid Lives
description: In his latest Graphic Content column, Ed Park looks at three books — including new work from Art Spiegelman and Simon Hanselmann — that have emerged from the months of pandemic.
content: On social media this spring, the prolific Tasmanian-born cartoonist Simon Hanselmann trashed the shiny digital revenue sources (Patreon, NFTs) some artists embrace, telling fans to buy his actual books, and extolled the power of his medium in its bedrock, pen-and-paper form: “Comics are better than TV, better than the internet, the best of all the arts. Pure visions. Autonomy.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bill Pennington
title: Headgear Reduces Concussions in High School Girls’ Lacrosse, Study Shows
description: A University of Florida study includes data from roughly 350,000 games and practices in more than 30 states. Headgear for girls has been mandated in Florida since 2015, and remains hotly debated.
content: In 2015, without empirical evidence or data that supported the decision, Florida became the only state to require high school girls’ lacrosse teams to wear protective headgear. Her father drove the six of them — two parents, four sisters — to a weekend showing where in her teenage naïveté she asked a salesperson if the furniture was included. Richard was the first person to train as a specialized emergency physician in Australia, and it seems wrong that Covid should end his career.
